title: Getting Started
content: Getting Started XL Converter is a powerful image converter for the latest formats. Downloading XL Converter There are only 3 official sources you can download it from. Patreon - support the project while getting the program The Official Website GitHub - for the tech savvy You should download XL Converter only from the aforementioned links. Installation Windows Double-click on the downloaded file. You will get a warning, click on More Info (link) Run Anyway (button) This happens for every program that hasn't rented an expensive digital signature, which serves no other purpose than to remove this popup. The Ardour developers put it nicely into words . Linux Unpack the archive Run ./install.sh A shortcut will be added to both the start menu and the desktop. Image Viewers You will need to install an image viewer with support for AVIF and JPEG XL. Windows ImageGlass - easiest to use XnViewMP PhotoQt PicView nomacs - alternatives Linux AVIF Install the package. sudo apt install libavif-gdk-pixbuf Detailed tutorial JPEG XL If you're security conscious, you might want to just stick with AVIF. Download the latest binaries for your distribution. Unpack then install them sudo dpkg -i *deb Detailed tutorial Updates Check for updates in the About tab . Is XL Converter Safe? The program is safe to use and the source code is publicly available.

title: Adding Files
content: Adding Files Add files (or folders) by dragging and dropping them onto the program. This works on every tab, not just the Input tab Alternatively, use the buttons at the bottom. Add Files - add selected files Add Folder - add all files from a folder (and its subfolders)

title: Choosing Output
content: < > Choosing Output Notice the top-left corner in the Output tab. Source Folder Each image will be saved in the same folder as its source. Custom All images will be saved to that particular folder. If a folder doesn't exist, it will be created. Copy and paste a path or click on the button with 3 dots to use a dialog. There are two types of paths: Absolute path (e.g. C:/Images/Converted ) Relative path (e.g. Converted ) - saves to a folder of that name next source image

title: Formats
content: Formats Formats - Introduction There are two types of compression: Lossy - file size shrinks along with the quality Lossless - file size can shrink, but the quality stays the same Formats - Overview Great quality at a small size and but not widely adopted and slow to convert. JPEG XL - great for both lossy and lossless AVIF - as good as JPEG XL at lossy Web standard, fast to convert and mostly supported. WEBP - a better replacement for JPG and PNG. Lossless mode works great and lossy is still decent. Large size, but compatible with everything. JPG - lossy only, a 30-year-old format with poor quality that people need to stop using PNG - lossless only Formats - Lossy JPEG XL Quality 90 - very high 80 - high quality and reasonable size 60 - space saving sweet-spot Effort - higher is better 7 - regular speed and good quality 9 - slow speed, better quality, and sometimes smaller file size Intelligent Effort - chooses the appropriate effort for the image type and settings. It prioritizes smaller file size, but often ends up also improving the quality. AVIF Constant Quality - lower is better quality and bigger size 20 - high quality and reasonable size 30 - space saving sweet-spot 40 - reasonable limit for space-saving (looks way worse than 30) 50 - very low quality Speed - lower is better 6 - good default 0 - very slow, best quality and smallest size WEBP Quality 90 - great quality, but large size 80 - good compromise between quality and size 60 - looks fine only far away, I wouldn't go any lower Formats - Lossless Manual Select JPEG XL, WEBP or PNG then check Lossless . The alternative, Lossless (only If smaller) converts to both lossy and lossless then picks the smaller one. It's especially useful with WEBP Smallest Lossless XL Converter features Smallest Lossless mode which converts to multiple formats then picks the smallest one. Use the checkboxes to disable the ones you don't want. Each format is good at a different thing JPEG XL - complex images (e.g. photographs) WEBP - simple images (e.g. screenshots) PNG - very simple images JPEG XL automatically appends JPG reconstruction data in this mode. JPEG XL vs AVIF The visual differences in lossy mode are negligible but one may perform slightly better in a given context. Preferred format: Text images - JPEG XL Full-page website screenshots - JPEG XL Photographs (high quality) - tie Anime drawings from Pixiv - AVIF Desktop screenshots - AVIF Photographs (low quality) - AVIF If you're unsure, try out both. These criteria are arbitrary and may not be representative. Technical differences AVIF is supported by most web browsers and JPEG XL isn't AVIF does not feature (a good) lossless mode AVIF is more secure (lower attack vector, based a video codec)

title: Downscaling
content: Downscaling Downscaling is available in the Modify tab . All methods maintain the same aspect ratio . They only scale the image down, not up. Dynamic Downscaling Choose Max File Size from the list and set the File Size (KiB) to your preferred value. File Size (KiB) - maximum allowed size Step (%) - smaller is more precise, but bigger is faster. Keep between 5% - 20% Tip: to preserve higher resolution, decrease the quality in the Format Tab . If a converted image is already smaller than the declared file size, no downscaling will occur. Manual Downscaling Percent Scales to that percentage. Example: 80% will result in a 20% smaller image Max Resolution Clamps the resolutions to fit in the selected range. Shortest and Longest Side Makes particular side fit under selected size. Helpful with vertical images. Resampling Methods By default, Lanczos will be used. You should not change this setting unless you have a very specific reason to. You can enable custom resampling in the Settings Tab ( Custom Resampling checkbox). Methods Lanczos - best default Point (a.k.a. Nearest Neighbor) - jagged edges Other methods are mostly useless on their own. Notes Intelliget Effort (in JPEG XL) is compatible with all downscaling types Downscaling is unavailable for animated images and in the "Smallest Lossless" mode

title: Shortcuts
content: Shortcuts General Alt + 1 - 5 - switch to a tab Input Tab Ctrl + A - select all Ctrl + Shift + X - clear list Delete - delete selected entries

title: Metadata
content: < > Metadata The metadata options are located in Modify Tab , over to the right. Up to Encoder... These options do not alter the final image, but whether your preferences are respected depends solely on the encoder used. Wipe - safely wipes metadata, with an exception of JPEG XL. Preserve - preserves basic metadata. ExifTool... Those options will ensure that metadata will always be handled the way you want it to. The conversion will take longer, because every file gets rewritten. Safe Wipe - deletes all except the data affecting the final image. Preserve - copies over all metadata. Unsafe Wipe - deletes every last bit of metadata, including color profile. It can potentially alter the final image. If you still have doubts, all metadata logic is contained within the Metadata.py module in the source code.

title: JPG Reconstruction
content: < > JPG Reconstruction All options are contained within the Output tab. Overview This feature allows you to: Convert existing JPG to JPEG XL losslessly (lowers size by 15% - 25%) Reconstruct the orignal JPG from JPEG XL Encoding Reconstruction Data Select JPEG XL format in the Output tab Check lossless Reconstruction data will be added to the generated JXL Note: the input file has to be a JPG, but its aliases (JPEG, JFIF...) are also supported. Increasing the Effort does reduce the file size slightly more. Reconstructing JPG Select PNG format Check Reconstruct JPG from JPEG XL A JPG will be generated instead of a PNG, If reconstruction data is found When To Use It? Use this method when your JPGs are already low quality or you don't want any more compression artifacts.

title: Settings
content: < > Settings General Dark Theme - the intended look of XL Converter Disable Downscaling on Startup - You will probably forget you have downscaling enabled the next time you turn on the program. This disables it for you. Disable Exception - disable the popups you get when conversion encounters soft errors. Input - Disable Sorting - disables sorting in the Input Tab , has no effect on performance. Conversion Downscaling - Custom Resampling - enables resampling mode selection in the Modify Tab . You should probably not change it.

title: Troubleshooting
content: Troubleshooting Bug Reports Send an email to contact@codepoems.eu Technical Supports Technical support is paid and available via Patreon . VCOMP140.DLL was not found Install Visual C++ Redistributables 2015 - 2022 . This is needed for ImageMagick to work. Doesn't Launch If the program won't launch, delete the following folder. Windows - %localappdata%/xl-converter Linux - ~/.config/xl-converter

title: FAQ
content: FAQ Is XL Converter free? Yes, even for commercial use. It's licensed under the GPLv3 . How does it make money then? It doesn't, which is why it could use your donation . Is XL Converter safe? Of course! The entire source is publicly available. Encoder binaries come either from the official sources or are compiled by myself. You can compile every part of this program yourself. All encoders are standard, which means you can easily swap them. What are the requirements? System: Windows 10 64-bit (1809 or later) Linux 64-bit (kernel 5.15 or later) Processor: a quad-core made in the last decade RAM: 4 GB minimum 8 GB recommended What are the "Intelligent Features"? They are my original concept, namely: Dynamic Downscaling Intelligent Effort Smallest Lossless Each one automates the conversion process in some way - saving you time. XL Converter is the first program to have such features.

title: Supported Formats
content: Supported Formats Images XL Converter features an image proxy, which allows you to convert from any image it can decode. For example HEIF -> AVIF. Animation support is limited, will not be expanded, and may be removed in the future.
